Severe acute fluoride toxicity: e.g., electrolyte disturbances such as hypocalcemia with neurologic and cardiac effects in extreme ingestion

Defined governance: Roles and accountability across water utility and public health, with reporting and oversight arrangements

Risk communication for families to reduce total fluoride ingestion from other sources (e.g., appropriate toothpaste amount/supervision for children, avoid swallowing), focused on the most susceptible ages: 0‑36 months old (rice‑sized grain of toothpaste), 3‑6 years old (small pea sized amount of toothpaste)

questions.title: Randomized Trial – Risk Measures (Calculations)
questions.stem:
People aged 50–60 years were randomized to annual FOBT or a control group and followed for 13 years.
Screened (n=15,570): 82 colorectal cancer deaths Control (n=15,394): 121 colorectal cancer deaths
Marking principle: For each calculation, award partial marks for Formula → Working → Answer/interpretation.
Sources (brief): CTFPHC, 2016

parts.prompt: Calculate the absolute risk reduction (ARR).
rubric: 1.5 marks total - Formula (0.5 mark): ARR = Risk(control) − Risk(screened) - Working (0.5 mark): 121/15,394 ≈ 0.00786; 82/15,570 ≈ 0.00527 - Answer + interpretation (0.5 mark): ARR ≈ 0.00259 (≈ 2.6 per 1,000 over 13 years)

parts.prompt: Calculate the relative risk reduction (RRR).
rubric: 1.5 marks total - Formula (0.5 mark) - Working (0.5 mark): RR ≈ 0.00527 / 0.00786 ≈ 0.67 - Answer (0.5 mark): RRR = 1 − RR ≈ 0.33 (≈ 33%)

parts.prompt: Calculate the number needed to screen (NNS).
rubric: 1.5 marks total - Formula (0.5 mark) - Working (0.5 mark): NNS = 1 / ARR - Answer (0.5 mark): NNS ≈ 386

questions.title: Standardization and Comparative Rates (High‑Marks Calculations)
questions.stem:
For practice purposes, consider the following hypothetical data on suicides in a small community compared with the overall provincial rate.
Table 1. Community suicides and population by age group, and provincial age‑specific suicide rates
Marking principle: For each calculation, award partial marks for Formula → Working → Answer/interpretation.
Sources (brief): Standard epidemiology methods (direct/indirect standardization)

parts.prompt: Calculate the crude RR compared with the provincial rate.
rubric: 1.5 marks total - Formula (0.5): RR = rate_community / rate_provincial - Working (0.5): community crude rate = 14/7,751 ≈ 0.001806; provincial rate = 16.4/100,000 = 0.000164 - Answer + interpretation (0.5): RR ≈ 11.0

parts.prompt: Calculate the SMR using indirect standardization.
Using direct standardization, calculate the age‑adjusted community rate (per 100,000) using a standard population of 10,000 per age group.
Using direct standardization and the same standard population, calculate the age‑adjusted provincial rate (per 100,000).
rubric: 2 marks total - Apply rates to standard (1): 0.70 + 2.10 + 2.27 + 1.26 = 6.33 (per 40,000) - Answer (0.5): (6.33/40,000)×100,000 ≈ 15.8 per 100,000 - Interpretation (0.5): provincial age‑adjusted rate in this standard is ~15.8/100,000

parts.prompt: Calculate the CMR using the age‑adjusted rates.
rubric: 1.5 marks total - Formula (0.5): CMR = adj rate_community / adj rate_province - Working (0.5): 121.0 / 15.8 ≈ 7.6 - Interpretation (0.5): age‑adjusted rate ~7.6× higher

parts.prompt: List FOUR epidemiologic observations about syphilis relevant to preventing congenital syphilis.
rubric: 0.5 mark each, 2 marks total Any FOUR: - Large increases since 2018; 2023 decrease does not establish a trend - Increasing rates among females of reproductive age - Congenital syphilis is preventable with timely screening and treatment - Many infections are asymptomatic, supporting routine screening - Reinfection is possible; partner management is essential

parts.prompt: List FOUR factors that increase risk of vertical transmission and/or adverse pregnancy outcomes.
rubric: 0.5 mark each, 2 marks total Any FOUR: - Stage (highest risk in primary/secondary) - Infection acquired near term - No/late prenatal care - No treatment or inadequate treatment; reinfection

parts.prompt: List THREE routes/timings of parent‑to‑infant syphilis transmission.
rubric: 0.5 mark each, 1.5 marks total - Transplacental transmission during pregnancy - Exposure to infectious lesions at delivery - Postnatal transmission through direct contact with infectious lesions (rare; breastfeeding itself not typical unless lesions on breast)

parts.prompt: List EIGHT public health interventions that reduce risk of congenital syphilis, addressing the pregnant person AND partner(s), across pregnancy, delivery, and postpartum.
rubric: 0.5 mark each, 4 marks total Any EIGHT: - Universal screening at first prenatal visit - Repeat screening later in pregnancy and/or at delivery when indicated by risk/outbreak guidance - Immediate treatment with penicillin per guidelines and ensure completion - Partner notification, testing and treatment to prevent reinfection - Case management to support follow‑up serology and prenatal care linkage - Risk reduction counselling; address structural risks and access barriers - Neonatal assessment plan when maternal infection is late or inadequately treated - Surveillance/reporting and outbreak response supports

questions.title: Newborn/Infant Infections + Immunization Timing
questions.stem:
Immunization timing: list TWO vaccines that can begin at 6 months of age (seasonal/routine recommendations) AND list FOUR vaccines commonly given around 12 months of age in many Canadian schedules.
Around 12 months (any FOUR; allow provincial variation): - MMR - Pneumococcal conjugate booster (commonly at 12 months in several schedules) - Meningococcal C conjugate (Men‑C‑C) (commonly at ~12 months) - Varicella (or MMRV where used; some schedules at 12–15 months) - Influenza (annual) - COVID‑19 (as recommended)
Marker note: Accept provincial schedule‑specific answers if internally consistent.
Sources (brief): PHAC Canadian Immunization Guide (recommended schedules), 2025–2026; Ontario routine schedule, 2025

parts.prompt: List SIX infections in the prenatal/newborn period that are high public health priority because they can cause severe outcomes and/or have clear prevention opportunities.
rubric: 0.5 mark each, 3 marks total Any SIX: - Hepatitis B - HIV - Syphilis - Rubella (congenital rubella syndrome prevention) - Varicella (congenital/neonatal varicella prevention) - Measles (high consequence; PEP and outbreak management) - Pertussis (severe infant disease; prevention via maternal Tdap) - Influenza (severe disease in infants; maternal vaccination + infant vaccination starting at 6 months)

questions.title: Child Health and Intersectionality – Food Insecurity and Malnutrition (Northern Remote Context)
questions.stem:
A 3‑year‑old child in a Northern remote Inuit community is seen for recurrent infections, poor growth, and fatigue. The family reports high food insecurity and limited access to affordable nutritious foods.
Sources (brief): Health Canada, 2019 (Canada’s Food Guide); Canada.ca pregnancy/healthy eating and supplements (general principles); Indigenous‑led food security frameworks (general)

parts.prompt: List EIGHT assessment elements you would prioritize (clinical, nutrition, environmental, and social).
rubric: 0.5 mark each, 4 marks total Any EIGHT: - Growth parameters and growth trajectory - Dietary history (24‑hour recall; food access constraints) - Screen for micronutrient deficiencies (iron deficiency anemia; vitamin D; others as clinically indicated) - Infection history and immunization status - Housing conditions (crowding, mould) and water security - Developmental screening and psychosocial assessment - Consider enteric/parasitic infection based on exposure history - Access to care and barriers (transport, language) - Household income supports and community food programs

parts.prompt: List EIGHT public health actions across individual, program, and structural levels.
rubric: 0.5 mark each, 4 marks total Any EIGHT: - Link to community‑led food programs (e.g., community freezer, school/daycare nutrition supports) - Culturally safe nutrition counselling supporting traditional foods where available - Coordinate micronutrient supplementation where indicated - Improve access to vaccines and infection prevention resources - Strengthen surveillance/monitoring of child growth and anemia indicators - Partner with Indigenous leadership; apply Indigenous data governance principles (e.g., OCAP®) - Advocate intersectorally on food affordability/logistics and housing/water infrastructure - Support policies/programs addressing poverty and cost of living

questions.title: Breast Cancer Screening – Program Evaluation, Equity, and Surveillance
questions.stem: A federal/provincial working group is reviewing breast cancer screening guidance and program performance in Canada.

parts.prompt: List FIVE criteria that an organized breast cancer screening program should meet to be considered effective and appropriate (benefits, harms, feasibility, and quality).
rubric: Any FIVE: target population/eligibility; benefit–harm balance incl overdiagnosis; acceptable test/protocol; diagnostic follow-up capacity; QA/audit; equitable access/cultural safety; performance monitoring; informed participation; cost/sustainability; continuous improvement.

parts.prompt: Provide TWO arguments supporting earlier/expanded screening AND TWO arguments supporting later/narrower screening (consider harms and equity).
rubric: Any TWO per side. Earlier/expanded: higher incidence at younger ages in some groups; higher baseline risk; equity concerns; years-of-life saved. Later/narrower: overdiagnosis/overtreatment; higher false positives/biopsies; anxiety/harms; uncertain mortality benefit in lower-risk; capacity/opportunity costs.

parts.prompt: List SIX attributes of a well-conducted public health surveillance system.
rubric: Any SIX: usefulness, simplicity, flexibility, data quality, acceptability, sensitivity, PVP, representativeness, timeliness, stability.

questions.title: Rapid Streptococcal Test – 2×2 Table and Diagnostic Accuracy
questions.stem: Rapid strep antigen test vs culture in 100 children. Culture+ 40, culture− 60. Results: TP 34, FN 6, FP 9, TN 51.

parts.prompt: Construct the 2×2 table and calculate sensitivity and specificity.
rubric: Sensitivity=34/(34+6)=0.85; Specificity=51/(51+9)=0.85. Partial marks: formula → working → answer.

parts.prompt: Calculate PPV and NPV.
rubric: PPV=34/(34+9)=0.79; NPV=51/(51+6)=0.90. Partial marks: formula → working → answer.

parts.prompt: Calculate LR+ and LR− and provide a one-sentence interpretation for each.
rubric: LR+=0.85/0.15≈5.7 (moderate rule-in). LR−=0.15/0.85≈0.18 (moderate rule-out). Partial marks: formula → working → answer/interpretation.

parts.prompt: If prevalence decreases, which metrics change most and why?
rubric: PPV decreases and NPV increases as prevalence decreases (base-rate effect).

questions.title: Opioid Toxicity – Dashboard Indicators and Intervention Package
questions.stem: A city has increasing opioid toxicity deaths and ED visits. Public health is asked to propose dashboard indicators and an intervention package.

rubric: Any SIX: deaths; non-fatal overdoses/ED; EMS calls; naloxone distribution/use; OAT coverage/retention; drug checking signals; supervised consumption utilization; housing instability; equity stratification where governed.

parts.prompt: List SIX interventions across the prevention spectrum (harm reduction → treatment → recovery).
rubric: Any SIX: naloxone distribution; supervised consumption/overdose prevention; safer supply; low-barrier OAT access; peer post-overdose outreach; shelter-based harm reduction; integrated mental health supports; housing-first partnerships.
